page.title: 14SHEEP FARMING, EAST BARKWITH
page.content: Many farms kept some{sheep,}but three had contrasting management methods. One farm of 162 acres in{East {Barkwith}had 25 breeding ewes, kept out in the field, which had 2 lambs each in late February - early March 1985.Most lambs would be sold off by the end of July, and new breeding ewes bought in. In{Benniworth}a unit of 5 farms,totalling 1400 acres, almost all arable, bought in up to 2000 sheep to fatten on sugar-beet tops during the winter. These would be sold when the sheep's weight and the market were ready. In{South Willingham}a farmer kept about 600 breeding ewes in polythene tents for protection when they lambed in January. They produced nearly 1000 lambs. The ewes were fed on a mixture of barley, fish meal and soya meal. In 1986, he plans to clip the ewes in January, to keep them cool
